channel.title: Unlock more potential with your Java Programs, use the Java Native Environment!
channel.description:
[center][size=18pt][b]Using the Java Native Environment[/b][/size][/center] This tutorial will teach you the basics of using the Java Native Interface (JNI), coupled with C++, to do a lot more with your programs. This will not be an explanation of the JNI and what it is; if you want that, click [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JNI]here[/url] This will be the 'dummies' guide, for people that have never used C++, and I will include pictures of what you will be doing in the IDE.
[u][b][size=12pt]Contents[/size][/b][/u]
[ul][li][iurl=#neededitems]Needed items[/iurl][/li] [li][iurl=#javacode]Writing the Java Code[/iurl][/li] [li][iurl=#makingheader]Making the C++ Header File[/iurl][/li] [li][iurl=#startingcppide]Starting the Microsoft Visual C++ IDE and making a DLL project[/iurl][/li] [li][iurl=#impheader]Importing our Tutorial header[/iurl][/li] [li][iurl=#finally]Writing the C++ code[/iurl][/li][/ul]
Before I get started, I'd like to thank abraham2119 for encouraging me to learn about using the JNI.
[anchor=neededitems][u][b]Needed items[/b][/u]
[ul][li]A C++ IDE (Microsoft Visual C++ 2010 is what I will be using in this example)[/li] [li]Java Development Kit[/li][/ul]
Once you have those things, we can get started.
[anchor=javacode][u][b]Writing the Java Code[/b][/u] The first thing you do when using the JNI is make a normal Java class. This class will be the one that loads the [b]Dynamic-link library[/b] (DLL), which you will be making later. Here is the example class we will be using in this tutorial, it is important to read the comments: [code=java]/** * * @author David */
public class Tutorial {
static { System.loadLibrary("TutorialDLL"); //Load the library we will be creating in C++ }
public native void nativeVoidInitialize(); // Native methods are methods that are handled in the C++ code library. public native void helloWorld(); //They can still be called in the Java program, as you will see below, but the library will handle them
void noParameters() { //These next three methods look like normal methods, and that's because they are. System.out.println("No parameters :)"); }
void getNativeParameters(int i) { //They can be called in the normal Java program, but they are also loaded into the JNI and can be called via the library System.out.println("Integer: " + i); }
void getTwoNativeParameters(int i, boolean b) { //There is a special way to load method ID's into the C++ code, which I will show you how to do if(b) { System.out.println("Boolean true, integer " + i); } else { System.out.println("Boolean false, integer " + i); } }
public static void main(String args[]) { Tutorial tut = new Tutorial(); //Makes an instance of this Tutorial class tut.nativeVoidInitialize(); //These are the native methods that will be handled by the C++ code, look up to see how they are declared tut.helloWorld(); //You can have as many native methods as you like! tut.noParameters(); //This is just showing that you can call these methods from inside the Java code, and in the C++ code (later) } [/code]
That's it! That's all the Java code you will be writing for this example.
[anchor=makingheader][u][b]Making the C++ Header File[/b][/u] Now that we have that, we need to make a [i]header[/i] file. Header files are used to declare things for other C++ files to use. You can read more about them [url=http://www.learncpp.com/cpp-tutorial/19-header-files/]here[/url]. The great thing about these header files is, you don't need to write them! In fact, they are generated for you using a simple batch script, and editing them is not suggested. Here's the batch script (make sure that the .bat is in the same place as your .java file)[code]@echo off echo JNI Tutorial - Compile and Create Header File - By Davidi2 title Compiling... "C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_18\bin\javac.exe" Tutorial.java echo Compiled! title Creating header file... "C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_18\bin\javah.exe" -jni Tutorial echo Tutorial.h header file created! pause[/code] This will create the Tutorial header file in the same folder as your other files. Do not open it yet, just leave it alone.
[anchor=startingcppide][u][b]Starting the Microsoft Visual C++ IDE and making a DLL project[/b][/u] Start MSVC++ if you haven't already. I will be using MVC++ [i]2010[/i], so depending on your IDE the steps might be different. Once it's loaded, follow these steps to create the C++ project: [img]http://img529.imageshack.us/img529/7435/tutorial1h.png[/img]
When the new project dialog shows, follow these steps: [img]http://img571.imageshack.us/img571/4674/tutorial2y.png[/img]
When the application wizard pops up, follow these steps: [img]http://img204.imageshack.us/img204/9016/tutorial3k.png[/img]
Project made!
[anchor=impheader][u][b]Importing our Tutorial header[/b][/u] Here comes the fun part. If you're using VS2010, like me, it will automatically create and open TutorialDLL.cpp (the cpp extension stands for C++) On the left, it [i]should[/i] have opened the Solution Explorer, which you can use to open other files that are part of the project. If it did not open for some reason, you can type in the shortcut [i]Ctrl+Alt+L[/i]. Now we need to import the header we made with that batch script! To get that started, follow these steps: [img]http://img842.imageshack.us/img842/1472/tutorial4.png[/img]
A dialog will pop up: [img]http://img89.imageshack.us/img89/6438/tutorial5.png[/img] (It says Tutorial, not Tutoriall; it was the cursor)
Now, a blank Tutorial.h code page should pop up. Now, minimize VC++, and navigate to the folder you have your java files in, as well as the batch file and generated header file. Right click and open Header.h [b]in notepad[/b]. Copy all of the code in there, and paste it in the empty Header.h we made in VC++. It should now look like this: [img]http://img823.imageshack.us/img823/7762/tutorial6.png[/img]
Now we need to fix that error. To do this, we are going to import the JNI include files. This step is tricky if you dont pay attention to the pictures. If you have problems, just comment. [anchor=properties] First, open the project properties. [img]http://img522.imageshack.us/img522/1606/tutorial7.png[/img]
Then [img]http://img403.imageshack.us/img403/3665/tutorial8.png[/img]
Then the hard(er) part [img]http://img694.imageshack.us/img694/1736/tutorial9n.png[/img]
If you imported those 2 folders (include, and include\win32) correctly, the error(s) in Header.h should be gone.
[anchor=finally][u][b]Writing the C++ code[/b][/u] Phew! That was a lot of work, and we didn't even start writing the code yet! Don't worry, it gets a little more fun now.
If you looked at TutorialDLL.cpp, you saw that it already had an import ("stdafx.h") Right below that line, add [code=cpp]#include "Tutorial.h"[/code]This line is very important. Not only is it our declarations for our Java methods, it also contains the JNI include line.
So now we can get started! Open up your Tutorial.java again. See the native voids? These are the methods that we need to cover. The way we write a Java method (for JNI) is like this: JNIEXPORT [b]type[/b] JNICALL Java_[b]ClassName[/b]_[b]MethodName[/b](JNIEnv *env, jobject obj) { } The bolded things are the ones we change, the normal ones we leave alone.
[b]Type[/b] - The type of method it is. void, String, integer etc [b]ClassName[/b] -> [b]Method name[/b] - Self-explanatory, they are the class names and method names JNIEnv and jobject you don't need to worry about at the moment. So here's how we would write the method for "public native void nativeVoidInitialize();" [code=cpp]JNIEXPORT void JNICALL Java_Tutorial_nativeVoidInitialize(JNIEnv *env, jobject obj) { }[/code]
It's that easy! So now, every time you call nativeVoidInitialize in your Java program, it will be handled here! This mean that you can do C++ things, from a Java program. Feel free to experiment around with this, but I'm going to continue the tutorial.
If you look back in your Java file, you see the normal methods, like getNativeParameters. The way you call these is not the same (because they are not native) In order to call a normal method, you need to have a JNI Environment, which you saw in JNIEnv *env.
Let's use this to our advantage.
[code=cpp]JNIEXPORT void JNICALL Java_Tutorial_nativeVoidInitialize(JNIEnv *env, jobject obj) { jclass tutorial = env->FindClass("Tutorial"); //Get the JNI class instance jmethodID gnp = env->GetMethodID(tutorial, "getNativeParameters", "(I)V"); //Finds the Tutorial method 'getNativeParameters'. env->CallVoidMethod(obj, gnp, 6); //This calls the method that we found in the previos line. All of the parts after the method ID are the methods parameters jmethodID gtnp = env->GetMethodID(tutorial, "getTwoNativeParameters", "(IZ)V"); //Finds the Tutorial method 'getTwoNativeParameters'. env->CallVoidMethod(obj, gtnp, 10, false); //This calls the method that we found in the previos line. All of the parts after the method ID are the methods parameters }[/code]You can get the gist of what each line does from the comments, but if you don't know C++, don't worry about it too much. Just try to memorize how to use the JNI specific methods. Even still, I will go a little more in depth into GetMethodID, because it is important.
GetMethodID(jclass, methodName, methodTypeAndParams); The first two are self-explanatory, but the second one, not so much. The method type goes like so: [i]"(Paramtypes)Methodtype"[/i] for example, (IZ)V indicates a void, with the params int, and then boolean. Here is a table of the basic representations: Z boolean B byte C char S short I int J long F float D double So let's summarize what the code does so far. We run Tutorial.java, which will call the native method nVI. This points to the DLL, which executes the code above. The code above gets an instance of the Tutorial class, then gets the method ID's for two different methods, and executes them with the parameters.
Here's the entire cpp code: [code=cpp]// TutorialDLL.cpp : Defines the exported functions for the DLL application. //
#include "stdafx.h" #include "Tutorial.h"
JNIEXPORT void JNICALL Java_Tutorial_nativeVoidInitialize(JNIEnv *env, jobject obj) { jclass tutorial = env->FindClass("Tutorial"); //Get the JNI class instance jmethodID gnp = env->GetMethodID(tutorial, "getNativeParameters", "(I)V"); //Finds the Tutorial method 'getNativeParameters'. env->CallVoidMethod(obj, gnp, 6); //This calls the method that we found in the previous line. All of the parts after the method ID are the methods parameters jmethodID gtnp = env->GetMethodID(tutorial, "getTwoNativeParameters", "(IZ)V"); //Finds the Tutorial method 'getTwoNativeParameters'. env->CallVoidMethod(obj, gtnp, 10, false); //This calls the method that we found in the previous line. All of the parts after the method ID are the methods parameters jmethodID np = env->GetMethodID(tutorial, "noParameters", "()V"); //Finds the Tutorial method 'noParameters'. env->CallVoidMethod(obj, np); //This calls the method that we found in the previous line. All of the parts after the method ID are the methods parameters (none, in this case) }
JNIEXPORT void JNICALL Java_Tutorial_helloWorld(JNIEnv *env, jobject obj) { //Handles the native method helloWorld printf("Hello World!\n"); //Equiv to System.out.print(); } [/code]
Now, we get to make our DLL! In the middle of the top toolbar, there is a green arrow. Next to it is a box that says 'Debug' Click the down arrow next to this box and change it to 'release'. When you do this, you may get errors again. This is because it changed your project properties. If it happens, go back and do [iurl=#properties]this step[/iurl] again.
Once you're error-free, click the green arrow to create the DLL. The output should be something like this: [code]------ Build started: Project: TutorialDLL, Configuration: Release Win32 ------ stdafx.cpp dllmain.cpp TutorialDLL.cpp Creating library c:\users\david\documents\visual studio 2010\Projects\TutorialDLL\Release\TutorialDLL.lib and object c:\users\david\documents\visual studio 2010\Projects\TutorialDLL\Release\TutorialDLL.exp Generating code Finished generating code TutorialDLL.vcxproj -> c:\users\david\documents\visual studio 2010\Projects\TutorialDLL\Release\TutorialDLL.dll ========== Build: 1 succeeded, 0 failed, 0 up-to-date, 0 skipped ==========[/code] Now, navigate to that project Foler\Release, and copy the TutorialDLL.dll Paste the DLL in your Java project folder (where your Java files are)
Execute your Java file (batch), and it should work!
Now, by editing what the C++ methods do, you can have Java programs that do C++ things. For example, setting hooks, or drawing directly onto the screen.
If you want me to go more in-depth on a part, just post with what you need.

item.title: Unlock more potential with your Java Programs, use the Java Native Environment!
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“super_, post:44, topic:373551”]it is Java Native Interface holy fucking shit[/quote]yea…

JNIEnv*

A JNI interface pointer (JNIEnv*) is passed as an argument for each native function mapped to a Java method, allowing for interaction with the JNI environment within the native method. This JNI interface pointer can be stored, but remains valid only in the current thread. Other threads must first call AttachCurrentThread() to attach themselves to the VM and obtain a JNI interface pointer. Once attached, a native thread works like a regular Java thread running within a native method. The native thread remains attached to the VM until it calls DetachCurrentThread() to detach itself. [3]

This is what I mean.

[quote=“Ix Soulcist xI, post:45, topic:373551”]Well, I’ll be using this as a reference if I ever switch languages. Thanks for the tutorial, hope this makes a some what difference.[/quote]Thanks

Read full topic
item.source: Unlock more potential with your Java Programs, use the Java Native Environment!

item.title: Unlock more potential with your Java Programs, use the Java Native Environment!
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“super_, post:40, topic:373551”]JNI works in any native language. it is also Java Native Interface, not Environment… not to mention that this in no way extends java’s abilities to use C++'s “oh so many features” more than allowing you to write native code to interact the your Java objects and what not.[/quote]I never said that it didn’t work with other languages, this tutorial is just for C++. Yes, but you use the Java Native Interface Environment (I don’t know if that’s exactly what it’s called); and I know the ‘I’ doesn’t stand for Environment lol.
And I don’t understand what you mean here? When I say ‘unlock more potential’ and what not, I just mean that using JNI allows you access to platform specific code, which you can’t do without using it.

PS - You guys can stop quoting ‘oh so many’, it was just a play off HcoJustins ‘oh so slightly greater’

Read full topic
item.source: Unlock more potential with your Java Programs, use the Java Native Environment!

item.title: Unlock more potential with your Java Programs, use the Java Native Environment!
item.dc:creator: @iKilem iKilem
item.description:
@iKilem wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:39, topic:373551”][quote author=iKilem link=topic=469560.msg3434723#msg3434723 date=1292672251]

You forgot to mention that this is ridiculously slow and is a pain in the ass manage. You posted a rather trivial example, but to be honest there aren’t many real applications using jni and most of them are probably better of done in raw java.

ps c++ sucks,
c > *

Quite funny, considering runescape uses the JNI quite a bit. Also, it’s not as slow as you make it out to be. It can be faster than pure java, but this obviously depends on what you are doing.

@Moparisthebest The JNI is useful mainly because of it being able to access OS-specific code, so don’t give us that portability bullshit.
[/quote]

The RuneScape client is also redundant in functionality. The portions of their native code to handle interfacing with OpenGL and DirectX aren’t needed, since they have their own 3D software renderer. Their 3D software renderer in native code is redundantly backed up with their pure-java software renderer. Thus, you can still run the RS client on any platform, just not 100% effectively on every platform.

There are advantages and disadvantages of using JNI, and sometimes it’s even necessary. I agree with the idea you should only use it if you absolutely need to, and if you only use it correctly. It’s pretty much pointless to write 95% of an application in Java, and the remaining 5% in C++ with OS dependencies that completely contradict the platform independent nature of the other 95% of the program. If you are going to make it platform dependent, why chose Java? There are generally better choices for applications only written in Windows, Mac, or other systems, if you are writing solely for that system.[/quote]
I wouldn’t say it’s redundant functionality. Some of the stuff that can be done using OpenGL/DirectX are not feasible in software rendering, given real-time constraints.

P.S. What I said to Moparisthebest was aimed at what he first said. I tl;dr’d the rest.

Read full topic
item.source: Unlock more potential with your Java Programs, use the Java Native Environment!

@Jython wrote:

JNI works in any native language. it is also Java Native Interface, not Environment… not to mention that this in no way extends java’s abilities to use C++'s “oh so many features” more than allowing you to write native code to interact the your Java objects and what not.

item.title: Unlock more potential with your Java Programs, use the Java Native Environment!
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“iKilem, post:38, topic:373551”][quote author=Fat Cookies link=topic=469560.msg3434059#msg3434059 date=1292606145]
You forgot to mention that this is ridiculously slow and is a pain in the ass manage. You posted a rather trivial example, but to be honest there aren’t many real applications using jni and most of them are probably better of done in raw java.

ps c++ sucks,
c > *
[/quote]
Quite funny, considering runescape uses the JNI quite a bit. Also, it’s not as slow as you make it out to be. It can be faster than pure java, but this obviously depends on what you are doing.

@Moparisthebest The JNI is useful mainly because of it being able to access OS-specific code, so don’t give us that portability bullshit.[/quote]

The RuneScape client is also redundant in functionality. The portions of their native code to handle interfacing with OpenGL and DirectX aren’t needed, since they have their own 3D software renderer. Their 3D software renderer in native code is redundantly backed up with their pure-java software renderer. Thus, you can still run the RS client on any platform, just not 100% effectively on every platform.

There are advantages and disadvantages of using JNI, and sometimes it’s even necessary. I agree with the idea you should only use it if you absolutely need to, and if you only use it correctly. It’s pretty much pointless to write 95% of an application in Java, and the remaining 5% in C++ with OS dependencies that completely contradict the platform independent nature of the other 95% of the program. If you are going to make it platform dependent, why chose Java? There are generally better choices for applications only written in Windows, Mac, or other systems, if you are writing solely for that system.

Read full topic
item.source: Unlock more potential with your Java Programs, use the Java Native Environment!

@Moparisthebest The JNI is useful mainly because of it being able to access OS-specific code, so don’t give us that portability bullshit.

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:33, topic:373551”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=469560.msg3434070#msg3434070 date=1292608145]

You forgot to mention that this is ridiculously slow and is a pain in the ass manage. You posted a rather trivial example, but to be honest there aren’t many real applications using jni and most of them are probably better of done in raw java.
[/quote]No… Look up some of the windows API stuff, and then figure out how to do it in raw Java. You need to use the JNI. The other way to do it would be to write it completely in the other language, but that’s not what this tutorial is.

And defeat the purpose of “Write once, run anywhere”…[/quote]Yea. But look up the percentages of OS use before judging it that harshly…

item.title: Unlock more potential with your Java Programs, use the Java Native Environment!
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:30, topic:373551”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=469560.msg3433708#msg3433708 date=1292562217]

The purpose is not to speed the program up, at all. It’s to allow you to use some of the oh so many features C++ has that Java doesn’t.

please enlighten what are these oh so many features you speak of?
[/quote]For example, setting hooks on WM messages…?

That isn’t a feature of C++, it’s part of the windows API, which you shouldn’t really be messing with anyway from a platform-independent language like Java.[/quote]Sorry, you’re right. But my point was advantages of using the JNI, not the language itself.

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:31, topic:373551”]You forgot to mention that this is ridiculously slow and is a pain in the ass manage. You posted a rather trivial example, but to be honest there aren’t many real applications using jni and most of them are probably better of done in raw java.[/quote]No… Look up some of the windows API stuff, and then figure out how to do it in raw Java. You need to use the JNI. The other way to do it would be to write it completely in the other language, but that’s not what this tutorial is.

item.title: Unlock more potential with your Java Programs, use the Java Native Environment!
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:16, topic:373551”][quote author=Miss Silabsoft link=topic=469560.msg3433699#msg3433699 date=1292561871]

The purpose is not to speed the program up, at all. It’s to allow you to use some of the oh so many features C++ has that Java doesn’t.

please enlighten what are these oh so many features you speak of?
[/quote]For example, setting hooks on WM messages…?[/quote]
That isn’t a feature of C++, it’s part of the windows API, which you shouldn’t really be messing with anyway from a platform-independent language like Java.

[quote=“John459, post:18, topic:373551”][quote author=Mendorphins link=topic=469560.msg3433714#msg3433714 date=1292563215]
I have no interest in C for the time being, but nevertheless, good job putting this out there. How long did your topic take to write? Mine took me 4 hours lol.
[/quote]

He isn’t talking about C?[/quote]
Actually JNI works for C or C++, or really any other native language if you want.

Nevertheless, there is more to it than this if you want a platform independent program, your native code has to be platform independent too, and you have to compile it for all targets, which is 64-bit windows, 32-bit windows, 32-bit Linux, 64-bit Linux, 64-bit OSX, PPC OSX, and possibly more I am forgetting. It’s a huge pain in the ass.

Read full topic

item.title: Unlock more potential with your Java Programs, use the Java Native Environment!
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:28, topic:373551”]You never got into native methods with any parameters at all. You only call ones from the Tutorial class, which I don’t understand why…[/quote]I don’t think you understand the point… the whole point is that a Java program (aka the Tutorial class) can call native methods that are also in the Java program, but the methods are handled in the DLL.

Read full topic
